title: 5Q: Reactivating the Original Intelligence and Capacity of the Body of Christ
author: Alan Hirsch

sections.title: Introduction
sections.summary: The introduction establishes APEST as a universal archetypal framework present throughout human culture, not limited to Christian contexts. It argues that the fivefold ministry functions have roots that precede conversion and are part of God's broader design for human flourishing and community organization. The chapter explores how archetypes, myths, and hero-expressions manifest across disciplines and demonstrates that 5Q (fivefold intelligence) provides a robust framework for understanding human thought and endeavor.

sections.title: In Praise of Soft Eyes
sections.summary: The preface introduces the concept of 'soft eyes' as a metaphor for perceiving deeper patterns and archetypal forms in ministry and life. It contrasts analytic (reductionist) thinking with synthetic (symphonic) thinking, arguing that the church needs the latter to see the whole picture of APEST. The author calls readers to approach the book with openness, laying aside conventional formulations and seeking the overarching framework that reveals ministry and church as never before.

sections.title: Chapter 1: RetroFuture — Biblical Foundations for a 5Q Future
sections.summary: This chapter establishes Ephesians 4:1-16 as the constitutional document for the church, presenting it as God's default settings for ecclesial life. It examines the three thematic sections: foundations for unity, the ascension gifting of APEST ministries, and the goal of attaining maturity and fullness in Christ. The chapter introduces the concept of 'Sense'—the ever-present primordial template of APEST that seeks expression in every church throughout history, even when suppressed.

sections.title: Chapter 2: The Universality and Origins of APEST: Archetypes, Myths, and Hero-Expression
sections.summary: This chapter explores the universal nature of APEST archetypes, demonstrating their presence in human culture before and beyond the church. It examines how God's gifts manifest through creation, the concept of vestigia Dei (traces of God), and how archetypes operate across philosophy, biology, psychology, and sociology. The chapter shows how APEST corresponds with contemporary typologies and argues that the fivefold framework is rooted in the imago Dei and ultimately in the being of God himself.

sections.title: Chapter 3: The Traces of God
sections.summary: This brief chapter continues the exploration of how APEST functions are not limited to the faith community but emerge from God's broader design. It examines the 'masks of God' and how archetypes manifest in culture, arguing that the fivefold typology is a category universal to humankind. The chapter emphasizes continuity between creational archetypes and their enhanced meanings in the Jesus movement.

sections.title: Scenius
sections.summary: This chapter expands on the concept of 'scenius' (collective creativity) and demonstrates how APEST archetypes function as forms of intelligence across all domains of society. It provides detailed examples of each fivefold archetype with cultural heroes, explores the metaphysics of APEST through the imago Dei, and traces the divine roots of each function. The chapter concludes by positioning APEST as a framework for systematizing theology with profound implications across church, society, and culture.

sections.title: Chapter 5: The Hero's Journey—The Movement That Jesus Started
sections.summary: This chapter explores how Jesus embodies the universal hero's journey pattern identified by Joseph Campbell. It examines how Jesus' story follows the classic quest-ordeal-return structure and demonstrates how he is the true hero who fulfills archetypal myths. The chapter connects the ascension gifting of APEST to the triumphal parade imagery, showing how Jesus redeems and reconstitutes the fivefold archetypes through recapitulation (anakephalaiosis), giving them as victory gifts to his church.

sections.title: Chapter 6: Embodiment—The Fivefold Modes of Jesus' Presence in the Church
sections.summary: This chapter demonstrates how Jesus perfectly embodies all five APEST functions, serving as the exemplary Apostle, Prophet, Evangelist, Shepherd, and Teacher. It explores the Body of Christ metaphor and argues that the church must mirror Christ's fivefold nature to be authentic. The chapter examines how Jesus' ministry is distributed through the Body, the problem of truncation when churches operate with only shepherd and teacher functions, and the necessity of all five functions for the church to extend Jesus' ministry and attain fullness.

sections.title: Chapter 7: Eph4Us—The Fivefold Functionality of the Church
sections.summary: This chapter shifts from biblical-theological exploration to practical application, examining how to embed 5Q into church life. It distinguishes between functions (organizational purposes) and callings (individual vocations), providing detailed definitions of each APEST function and its associated calling. The chapter explores how historical renewal movements recovered lost APEST functions, examines the dangers of dominant functions creating imbalance, and emphasizes the need for all five functions to work together for organizational health and maturity.

sections.title: Chapter 8: Marking the Body
sections.summary: This chapter proposes APEST as the marks of a true church, moving beyond traditional institutional markers. It critiques traditional Catholic and Protestant marks as reductive and argues for fivefold marks: apostolic (missional), prophetic (holy and just), evangelistic (proclaiming good news), shepherding (reconciled community), and teaching (wisdom and truth). The chapter positions these marks as both metrics and diagnostic tools, enabling leaders to assess strengths, identify deficiencies, and develop strategies for holistic maturity.

sections.title: 5Q: Reactivating the Original Intelligence and Capacity of the Body of Christ
sections.summary: This chapter provides practical tools and exercises for embedding APEST into church life at individual, local, and system levels. It introduces tools such as the Personal APEST Portrait, APEST Thinking Hats, Base and Phase exercises, APEST Inventory, APEST Perspectives, and APEST Pipeline for leadership development. The chapter emphasizes that transformation happens through practice and habit formation, not just knowledge, and provides frameworks for assessing and developing fivefold culture in organizations.

sections.title: Chapter 10: To Get From Here to There
sections.summary: This chapter, written by Rich Robinson, provides guidance for the journey of implementing 5Q in churches and organizations. It emphasizes learning by process rather than just answers, calls for repentance and 'soft eyes,' and outlines steps for the 5Q journey: being like a child, being a padawan (apprentice), being a long-distance runner, being an explorer, and being an architect. The chapter encourages starting small, journeying with others, and staying connected to 5Q resources and community.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.summary: The conclusion offers a brief poetic reflection on the journey of exploration, suggesting that through the process of discovery, we arrive where we started but know the place for the first time.

sections.title: 5Q: Reactivating the Original Intelligence and Capacity of the Body of Christ
sections.summary: This appendix addresses cessationist arguments that claim apostolic and prophetic functions ceased with the New Testament canon. It critiques these arguments by examining the roles of original apostles, distinguishing between doctrine and function, and demonstrating that the logic of Ephesians 4 requires all five functions to be simultaneously present. The appendix argues that cessationism rests on later church assumptions rather than New Testament teaching and calls for a return to the original design.

sections.title: 5Q: Reactivating the Original Intelligence and Capacity of the Body of Christ
sections.summary: This appendix addresses the misappropriation of APEST typologies as hierarchical leadership structures, particularly in Pentecostal-Charismatic and New Apostolic Reformation contexts. It argues that APEST is given to the entire Body, not just leaders, and must be shaped by Christ's humility and self-emptying rather than worldly power dynamics. The appendix emphasizes that ministry should emerge from within distributed gifts rather than being imposed from above.

sections.title: 5Q: Reactivating the Original Intelligence and Capacity of the Body of Christ
sections.summary: This appendix, co-written with Tim Catchim, examines the 'exiling' of Apostle, Prophet, and Evangelist (APE) functions from mainstream church life. It explores how the dominant Shepherd-Teacher model has led to organizational equilibrium and stasis, making the church incapable of adaptive change and missional engagement. The appendix calls for restoring the necessary dialectic between APE and ST functions for the church's renewal and mission effectiveness.

sections.title: 5Q: Reactivating the Original Intelligence and Capacity of the Body of Christ
sections.summary: This appendix compares the traditional threefold office (Prophet, Priest, King) with the fivefold APEST framework, arguing that the latter is more biblically consistent and practically nuanced. It explores how APEST functions manifest in Jesus' ministry, examines the extra-ecclesial dimensions of the orders of creation, and addresses concerns about hierarchical interpretations. The appendix emphasizes that the church exists to extend Christ's ministry and that getting the APEST model right is crucial for mission and witness.

sections.title: 5Q: Reactivating the Original Intelligence and Capacity of the Body of Christ
sections.summary: This section contains bibliographic references and citations used throughout the book, including works by theologians, biblical scholars, and missional thinkers who inform the 5Q framework and APEST typology.
